SUMMARY: NESTED | FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD DETAIL: FIELD | CONSTR | METHOD

com.nokia.dempsy.config
Class ApplicationDefinition

java.lang.Object
  com.nokia.dempsy.config.ApplicationDefinition

public class ApplicationDefinition
extends Object

Configuration should be thought of as an xpath with ApplicationDefinition at the root element and ClusterDefinitions as the child elements. It's used to layout the topology of an entire Dempsy appliation. Let's say the following simple processing pipeline constitutes a Dempsy application:

 
      SimpleAdaptor -> SimpleMessageProcessor

The straightforward configuration that accepts all of the defaults would be:

 
 new ApplicationDefinition("my-application").add(
   new ClusterDefinition("adaptor-stage",new SimpleMessageAdaptor()),
   new ClusterDefinition("processor-stage",new SimpleMessageProcessor()));

As an example using Spring, your application context would contain:

 
 <bean class="com.nokia.dempsy.config.ApplicationDefinition">
    <property name="applicationName" value="my-application" />
    <property name="clusterDefinitions">
       <list>
          <bean class="com.nokia.dempsy.config.ClusterDefinition">
             <constructor-arg name="clusterName" value="adaptor-stage" />
             <property name="adaptor" >
                <bean class="SimpleMessageAdaptor" />
             </property>
          </bean>
          <bean class="com.nokia.dempsy.config.ClusterDefinition">
             <constructor-arg name="clusterName" value="processor-stage" />
             <property name="messageProcessorPrototype">
                <bean class="SimpleMessageProcessor" />
             </property>
          </bean>
       </list>
    </property>
 </bean>

Notice, when using a dependency injection framework, you have the ability to configure your prototypes (MessageProcessors) and Adaptors independently from Dempsy. The Dempsy ApplicationDefinition would then be the point where you define the topology of processing chain. This nicely decouples the two concerns.

While any DI framework can be used if you then join the ApplicationDefinition to a Dempy instance (by hand), this is unnecessary when using either Spring or Guice as both are supported out-of-the-box.

Note: for ease of use when configuring by hand (not using a dependency injection framework like Spring or Guice) all "setters" (all 'mutators' in general) return the ApplicationDefinition itself for the purpose of chaining.

public ApplicationDefinition setSerializer(Object serializer)

getRoutingStrategy

public Object getRoutingStrategy()
Get the currently overridden RoutingStrategy for this ApplicationDefinition

setRoutingStrategy

public ApplicationDefinition setRoutingStrategy(Object routingStrategy)
Override the default RoutingStrategy for this ApplicationDefinition. Note the Object passed must be an instance of com.nokia.dempsy.routing.RoutingStrategy. Note that RoutingStrategy overriding is not for the faint of heart. We plan on eventually providing a standard means of selected between out-of-the-box RoutingStrategys.

getStatsCollectorFactory

public Object getStatsCollectorFactory()
Get the currently overridden StatsCollector for this ApplicationDefinition

setStatsCollectorFactory

public ApplicationDefinition setStatsCollectorFactory(Object statsCollectorFactory)
Override the default StatsCollector for this ApplicationDefinition Note the Object passed must be an instance of com.nokia.dempsy.monitoring.StatsCollectorFactory. While this could be used to completely replace the implementation of the StatsCollector, a more common use case would be to define one or more MetricsReporterSpecs to the default factory. in order to emit statistics to monitors like Graphite or Ganglia.

getExecutor

public Object getExecutor()
Get the currently configured DempsyExecutor for this Application.

setExecutor

public ApplicationDefinition setExecutor(Object dempsyExecutor)
You can set a custom Executor for worker threads. See DempsyExecutor in the lib-dempsycore for the definition of this interface. There is a DefaultDempsyExecutor that can be used and configured for the number of worker threads either directly or by some factor of the number of cores.

initialize

public void initialize()
                throws DempsyException
This is called from the Dempsy framework itself so there is no need for the user to call it.
